Compared to alternative imaging modalities, TTE has lower sensitivity in diagnosing aortic pathologies.

C) INCORRECT:

Emergency surgical repair is indicated for a ruptured/leaking TAA or aortic dissection, both of which can appear as a widened mediastinum on chest x-ray. However, both conditions cause severe thoracic pain (often indistinguishable from an acute myocardial infarction) and hemodynamic instability (tachycardia, hypotension, sometimes hypertension) is typically present. Emergency surgical repair is not an appropriate management option for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is an appropriate option if the cause of the widened mediastinum on a chest x-ray is aortic unfolding, the most common cause of this finding in older adults. However, aortic unfolding appears as an opened-up aortic arch on chest x-ray; it does not cause a tracheal shift. This patient has x-ray findings that are highly consistent with a TAA, which should be further investigated and confirmed or ruled out.

E) CORRECT:

A CT angiography (CTA) of the chest is the preferred imaging modality for investigating mediastinal abnormalities detected on chest x-ray (e.g., mediastinal widening or a mediastinal mass) as it is accurate, rapid, and non-invasive. This patient's x-ray findings are strongly suggestive of a TAA, which can manifest with chest discomfort and cough due to compression of the tracheobronchial tree (although most TAAs are asymptomatic, and this patient's cough may be a sequela of his recent upper respiratory tract infection). However, a chest x-ray cannot accurately determine the underlying cause of mediastinal widening. CTA is the best confirmatory test for TAAs, delineates the size and length of the TAA, and detects complications (e.g., thrombus formation, free/contained TAA rupture), thereby providing valuable information for planning management. MR angiography is a reasonable alternative to CTA in hemodynamically stable patients who should avoid ionizing radiation.

Key learning point: CT angiography is the preferred confirmatory test for thoracic aortic aneurysm in stable patients with mediastinal widening seen on chest x-ray.
questions.hint: This patient's chest x-ray shows bulging of the aorta (aortic knob or prominent shadow of the aortic arch) and a widened mediastinum. These findings are suggestive of a thoracic aortic aneurysm (TAA).

questions.text: You are seeing a 35-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department by ambulance because of sudden-onset confusion. His sister reports that he experienced a sudden, severe headache just minutes before becoming confused. He is currently able to answer simple questions. His temperature is 37.2°C, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Neurologic examination reveals normal visual fields, symmetric pupils, normal strength and deep-tendon reflexes bilaterally. CT of the head shows blood in the subarachnoid space. Which one of the following conditions is most likely to have led to this presentation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has a typical presentation of a subarachnoid hemorrhage. By far, the most common cause of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhages is a ruptured intracranial aneurysm. Intracranial aneurysms are abnormal focal outpouchings of cerebral arteries that can occur in any part of the intracranial circulation.

Key learning point: Ruptured intracranial aneurysms are the most common cause of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhages.

B) INCORRECT:

Pituitary apoplexy is most commonly due to bleeding from a benign pituitary tumor. Symptoms can include sudden-onset headache and vision loss, as well as symptoms of adrenal insufficiency or other pituitary hormonal deficiencies.

C) INCORRECT:

Giant-cell arteritis, an inflammatory disease of large blood vessels, typically manifests with headache, temple pain, and diplopia. As the condition worsens, patients may experience occlusion of the arteries that supply the optic nerve or retina, resulting in blindness. Subarachnoid hemorrhage is not a feature. Confirmation of the diagnosis is achieved via biopsy of the temporal artery.

D) INCORRECT:

Ischemic stroke accounts for 87% of all stroke cases and can be either thrombotic (80% of ischemic strokes) or embolic (20% of ischemic strokes). Clinical features depend on the location and extent of the blocked cerebral artery but can include focal weakness, sensory changes, diminished levels of consciousness, dizziness, and vision loss. This patient’s presentation is not typical of ischemic stroke.

E) INCORRECT:

Cerebral venous thrombosis results from a thrombus in the brain’s venous sinuses. Symptoms can include headache, visual disturbances, weakness of the face and limbs, and seizure activity. Cerebral venous thrombosis does not result in subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: You are seeing a 67-year-old woman who is brought to the emergency department by her daughter after losing consciousness at home. Her daughter reports that the patient had a diffuse headache and nausea about 2 hours before the episode. There was no recent trauma, and she was sitting in a chair when she lost consciousness. Her medical history includes hypertension, and her current medications are amlodipine, a daily multivitamin, and acetaminophen. Her pulse is 92/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 158/100 mm Hg. On examination, she is disoriented and has nuchal rigidity. A CT scan of the head reveals a diffuse hemorrhage at the base of the brain. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intracranial arteriovenous malformations cause 10% of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhages. Arteriovenous malformations would have shown up on the CT as foci of calcification and hyperattenuating vascular channels.

B) INCORRECT:

Intracranial artery dissection is a rare cause of subarachnoid hemorrhage. The majority of cases occur in people between the ages of 35–50 years. Intracranial artery dissection is usually preceded by a history of trauma, exertional activity, or cerebral artery stretching, which can occur with migraines or sudden elevations of blood pressure. Even though this patient does have increased blood pressure, it is not dramatically high. There is also no history of trauma.

C) INCORRECT:

Spinal arteriovenous malformations are a rare cause of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage. These malformations are often located in the cervical cord or craniocervical junction, and rupture presents with prominent back or neck pain, which is absent in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Ruptured saccular aneurysms are the cause of 80% of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhages. This patient has several risk factors for the development of a saccular aneurysm, including age > 40 years, female gender, and hypertension. Other risk factors for a saccular aneurysm include cigarette smoking, heavy alcohol use, connective tissue disorders, polycystic kidney disease, and family history.

Key learning point: Ruptured saccular (berry) aneurysms are the most common cause of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage, especially in older adults with risk factors like hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

A ruptured mycotic aneurysm is a rare cause of nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhages. Mycotic intracranial aneurysms result from infected emboli, most often secondary to infective endocarditis. This patient does not have any signs or symptoms such as fever, cardiac murmurs, bacteremia, or cutaneous lesions (Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, or Roth spots) that would suggest infection or endocarditis.
questions.hint: Sudden-onset headache, nuchal rigidity, and diffuse hemorrhage at the base of the brain on a CT scan are suggestive of a subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: You are caring for a 16-year-old boy who is hospitalized with a severe, sudden-onset headache and no preceding history of trauma. He undergoes cerebral angiography (figure provided). Which one of the following initial steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Provide reassurance; repeat imaging in 5 years.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic initiation of antiseizure medications, such as phenobarbital, to prevent a first seizure is generally not recommended, because there is little evidence for prophylactic antiseizure medication after neurosurgery. Phenobarbital, in particular, has significant adverse effects (such as sedation), which can make it difficult to clinically monitor the patient.

B) CORRECT:

Cerebral AVMs are considered sporadic congenital vascular lesions, but their pathogenesis is not well understood. Despite their congenital nature, cerebral AVMs often become symptomatic only in the second to fourth decades of life. Rupture with intracranial hemorrhage is the most frequent complication and clinical presentation of AVMs in children; affected patients experience sudden onset of severe headache, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, and focal neurologic deficits. Unruptured AVMs manifest as headache, seizures, and progressive neurologic dysfunction.

Acute intervention is recommended for children and young adults with AVMs, even when asymptomatic, because there is a 1% annual risk for hemorrhage, which compounds to a high lifetime risk given the long life expectancy in this age group.

The optimal type of therapy for AVMs is a subject of debate. Microsurgical resection remains the gold standard for treating accessible AVMs, especially in cases with intracranial hemorrhage. More recently, embolization and radiosurgery are being used. Embolization alone does not provide complete resolution of AVMs; it is typically used in advance of surgery to reduce blood loss and to reduce the size of the AVM. Radiosurgery is used for patients with recurrent, large, deep-seated or eloquently located AVMs, although the long-term neurodevelopmental effects of radiation from radiosurgery have not been fully elucidated. Children with AVMs should be followed closely even after cure, because there is a small possibility of late AVM recurrence in young populations.

Key learning point: Treatment of arteriovenous malformations in children should include embolization or surgical resection, given the 1% annual risk for hemorrhage.

C) INCORRECT:

Given the risk of hemorrhage, this patient should not be started on antiplatelet therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Given the risk of hemorrhage, this patient should not be started on anticoagulant therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute intervention is recommended for children and young adults with AVMs, even when asymptomatic, because there is a 1% annual risk for hemorrhage, which compounds to a high lifetime risk given the long life expectancy in this age group. Thus, offering reassurance to this patient with repeat imaging would not be sufficient.
questions.hint: Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) are formed by abnormal connections between the arterial and venous systems, by which arterial blood flows directly into the venous efferent vessels without a capillary bed between them. Given the high blood flow in these malformed vessels, they become enlarged and their walls become weak. If large enough, AVMs in the brain can cause high cardiac output and, in extreme cases, may result in cardiac failure. Aside from hemorrhages of early infancy and prematurity, AVMs are the most common lesions associated with spontaneous intracranial hemorrhage in children.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with acute-onset abdominal pain that began less than an hour ago. He rates the pain as 8/10 and describes it as constant. Medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and a 30-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs are BP, 90/55; P, 115; T, 36.8°C (98.2°F); oxygen saturation, 96% on room air. Physical examination shows a tender epigastric mass. Point-of-care ultrasound shows aortic dilatation to 4.8 cm. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel
Administer morphine and reassess in 30 minutes
Initiate fluid resuscitation and contact vascular surgery
Obtain CT angiography of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Electrocardiogram and chest x-ray are not the most important initial steps in this clinical scenario. While a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm can mimic acute myocardial infarction, these studies would delay appropriate management of the suspected rupture.

B) INCORRECT:

Laboratory studies are not specific for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) rupture and should not delay definitive management. While a CBC may show decreased hemoglobin from blood loss, normal values do not exclude rupture. In unstable patients with a suspected ruptured AAA, operative intervention should not be delayed for laboratory results.

C) INCORRECT:

Pain management alone is inappropriate as the initial step in a patient with a suspected ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. While IV opioids may be used as adjunctive therapy, they must be titrated carefully as they may worsen hypotension. The priority is hemodynamic stabilization and urgent surgical evaluation.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with hypotension and abdominal pain, and point-of-care ultrasound findings are consistent with an abdominal aortic aneurysm in an unstable state. The most appropriate immediate step in management includes fluid resuscitation (targeting permissive hypotension with systolic blood pressure 70–90 mm Hg) and emergency vascular surgery consultation for operative repair.

E) INCORRECT:

While CT angiography can provide valuable anatomical information for operative planning, this patient is hemodynamically unstable with a suspected ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The diagnosis should be considered clinical in unstable patients; imaging should not delay definitive management. CT may be considered after vascular surgery consultation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of hypertension presents with severe right groin pain and swelling 8 hours after outpatient coronary angiography. Examination shows a 4-cm tender, pulsatile mass with an audible bruit. Vital signs are normal, and distal pulses are intact. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

True femoral artery aneurysms are dilated vessels surrounded by all three vessel layers and are most commonly caused by atherosclerosis. Femoral artery aneurysms do not typically develop acutely after a catheterization procedure.

B) INCORRECT:

While retroperitoneal hematomas can be a complication of femoral artery catheterization, they typically manifest with flank, back, or abdominal pain rather than a pulsatile groin mass.

C) INCORRECT:

Abscesses manifest as tender, fluctuant masses with signs of infection but do not have pulsatile flow or produce a bruit. Additionally, abscesses typically develop over days to weeks rather than acutely after an invasive procedure.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – Pseudoaneurysms are the most common complication after femoral artery cannulation, occurring in approximately 1% of patients. Characteristic features include postcannulation groin pain, a pulsatile mass, and an audible bruit or thrill. These findings result from persistent communication with the arterial lumen, which allows blood flow into the pseudoaneurysmal cavity.

E) INCORRECT:

Arterial thrombosis typically manifests with signs of acute limb ischemia, including absent or diminished distal pulses, rather than a pulsatile mass with intact circulation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents with sudden-onset severe chest pain radiating to his back. Blood pressure is 190/110 mm Hg in the right arm and 160/90 mm Hg in the left arm. Heart rate is 105 bpm. Chest x-ray is shown. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate next diagnostic step?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with classic high-risk features of aortic dissection, including sudden severe chest and back pain, a blood pressure differential between the arms, and a widened mediastinum on chest x-ray. CT angiography is the gold standard definitive imaging modality for aortic dissection in stable patients and provides essential information for operative planning (e.g., visualization of the intimal dissection flap and double lumen and the extent of involvement).

B) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography may be used as an initial screening tool for aortic dissection in unstable patients but has limited sensitivity and cannot reliably rule out the diagnosis. As this patient is stable and clinical suspicion is high, definitive imaging is indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

D-dimer alone is not recommended to rule out aortic dissection due to low sensitivity. This patient's clinical presentation raises strong suspicion for aortic dissection, and another diagnostic step is more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography is primarily indicated for unstable patients, patients with contraindications to iodinated contrast, or when immediate bedside imaging is needed. As this patient is stable and clinical suspicion for aortic dissection is high, definitive imaging is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

MR angiography has high sensitivity and specificity for aortic dissection but is time-consuming and not always readily available. A different modality is preferred for stable patients with suspected aortic dissection.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of unilateral occipital headache and posterior neck pain that began after vigorous coughing. She reports no visual changes or weakness but today developed mild dizziness, vertigo with head movement, and difficulty swallowing. Physical examination shows subtle dysarthria. Vital signs are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis requiring immediate evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Meningitis typically manifests with fever, neck stiffness, and photophobia. The specific trigger event of coughing and the gradual development of vertebrobasilar symptoms are more consistent with another condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Tension headache would not cause neurological symptoms such as dysarthria and vertigo. The unilateral occipital location and neck pain following a specific trigger suggest a secondary headache disorder.

C) INCORRECT:

Cervical strain does not typically cause neurological symptoms such as dysarthria and vertigo. The sudden onset after coughing and the specific symptom pattern suggest a vascular rather than musculoskeletal pathology.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of sudden-onset occipital headache and posterior neck pain following a trigger event (coughing), as well as features of vertebrobasilar insufficiency such as dysarthria and vertigo, strongly suggests vertebral artery dissection.

E) INCORRECT:

Migraine with brainstem aura can manifest with dysarthria, vertigo, and headache. However, migraine with brainstem aura typically manifests with fully reversible brainstem symptoms preceding the headache; it does not usually cause progressive neurological symptoms over multiple days.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with progressive dyspnea and reduced exercise tolerance. She had an anterior MI treated with percutaneous coronary intervention 5 weeks ago. Physical examination shows a laterally displaced apical impulse and a holosystolic murmur. ECG shows ST elevation in leads V2–V4. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Postmyocardial infarction syndrome (also known as Dressler syndrome) is a type of autoimmune pericarditis that occurs 2–10 weeks after MI. It typically manifests with pleuritic chest pain, fever, and friction rub, in addition to diffuse ST elevations on ECG, not localized persistent anterior lead changes.

B) INCORRECT:

Left ventricular pseudoaneurysms typically occur in the first two weeks after MI and result in nonspecific ST changes. In addition, left ventricular pseudoaneurysms most commonly occur in the posterior or lateral ventricular wall, whereas this patient's ECG findings suggest that the anterior wall is affected.

C) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture typically occurs within days of MI and manifests with acute severe mitral regurgitation and rapid clinical deterioration. This patient's chronic presentation and persistent ST elevation on ECG suggest a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defect typically occurs days after MI and manifests with a harsh holosystolic murmur and acute deterioration. This patient's laterally displaced apical impulse and anterior ST elevation pattern are more consistent with a different diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – A laterally displaced apical impulse, which indicates left ventricular enlargement, and persistent ST elevation more than 2 weeks after MI are consistent with ventricular aneurysm. The holosystolic murmur suggests mitral regurgitation from annular dilation and further supports this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a severe headache that began 4 hours ago. She mentions having a similar but less severe headache with brief double vision one week ago that resolved spontaneously. Vital signs are normal. Neurological examination is normal except for mild neck stiffness. CT head without contrast shows no acute abnormalities. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Empiric sumatriptan and reassessment in 2 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharge is inappropriate due to this patient's history of prodromal symptoms suggestive of a sentinel leak. The combination of severe headache with a preceding episode of headache and transient diplopia raises concern for aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage, which requires further evaluation even with a negative initial CT.

B) INCORRECT:

While MRI may eventually be useful for ruling out other causes of headache, this patient's clinical presentation suggests a sentinel leak, and therefore more specific evaluation for subarachnoid hemorrhage is required.

C) INCORRECT:

Observation alone is inadequate. This patient's prodromal symptoms and current severe headache strongly raise suspicion for aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage, which requires active diagnostic evaluation rather than watchful waiting.

D) INCORRECT:

Empiric treatment with sumatriptan without further workup is inappropriate because this patient's history suggests a sentinel leak. This approach could lead to dangerous delays in diagnosis and treatment of a potentially life-threatening condition.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Severe headache with a preceding episode of headache and transient diplopia raises suspicion for a sentinel leak, which can precede aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). Despite the negative noncontrast CT, second-line testing with either lumbar puncture or CT angiography is warranted to evaluate for SAH.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents with a 6-hour history of severe left calf pain and foot numbness. Examination shows diminished pedal pulses and a palpable pulsatile mass in the popliteal fossa. Duplex ultrasound shows the popliteal artery with a diameter of 2.3 cm and intraluminal echogenic material. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Baker cyst (popliteal cyst) can manifest as a popliteal mass but is not pulsatile and does not cause arterial insufficiency. Ultrasound would show a fluid-filled cystic structure, not arterial dilatation with intraluminal thrombus.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – A pulsatile popliteal mass, ultrasound findings of arterial dilatation with intraluminal echogenic material (thrombus), and clinical signs of distal arterial insufficiency strongly raise suspicion for popliteal aneurysm with thrombosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Deep vein thrombosis can cause calf pain and swelling but does not produce a pulsatile mass or arterial insufficiency with diminished pedal pulses. In addition, ultrasound would show a noncompressible vein with reduced or absent venous flow.

D) INCORRECT:

Popliteal artery entrapment syndrome typically affects younger individuals and manifests with exercise-induced claudication. In addition, aneurysmal arterial dilatation on imaging and this patient's acute presentation with thrombosis are not consistent with popliteal artery entrapment syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Arterial embolism can cause acute limb ischemia with pain and diminished pulses but would not manifest with a palpable pulsatile mass or show arterial dilatation on ultrasound.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with severe headache and neck pain that began 4 hours ago. He has a history of hypertension and takes warfarin for atrial fibrillation. Physical examination shows left ptosis and miosis with no other focal deficits. CT head shows no acute abnormalities. His INR is 3.2. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Reverse anticoagulation with fresh frozen plasma

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Severe headache, neck pain, and partial Horner syndrome are consistent with cervical artery dissection. CTA head and neck is the first-line imaging study to evaluate for cervical dissections. Establishing the diagnosis is the priority before determining the optimal antithrombotic approach, especially in patients taking anticoagulants.

B) INCORRECT:

Reversing anticoagulation is premature without confirming the diagnosis. This patient's elevated INR actually provides some protection against thrombotic complications if a dissection is present, and reversal may increase stroke risk.

C) INCORRECT:

Adding antiplatelet therapy in a patient with an INR of 3.2 who is already taking anticoagulants would significantly increase bleeding risk. The optimal antithrombotic approach should be determined after confirming the diagnosis and assessing bleeding risk.

D) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is inappropriate in this anticoagulated patient with features suggestive of cervical artery dissection. With an INR of 3.2, lumbar puncture carries a significant risk of epidural hematoma and spinal cord compression.

E) INCORRECT:

Adding heparin to existing warfarin therapy in a patient with an INR of 3.2 would result in excessive anticoagulation, substantially increasing the risk of bleeding. This approach is not supported without first confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents with acute-onset left hemiparesis and dysarthria. His history includes MI treated with percutaneous coronary intervention six weeks ago. Vital signs are BP, 118/72; P, 82. Physical examination shows a displaced apical impulse with a grade 2/6 systolic murmur. ECG shows ST elevations in the anterior leads. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current presentation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's displaced apical impulse, systolic murmur, and persistent anterior ST elevations indicate ventricular aneurysm formation following anterior MI. Ventricular aneurysms create an environment of blood stasis that increases the risk of left ventricular thrombus formation. Subsequent thromboembolism causes stroke, resulting in acute neurological deficits.

B) INCORRECT:

While ST elevations may indicate reocclusion, this patient had an MI 6 weeks ago, making another cause more likely. In addition, left hemiparesis and dysarthria are not consistent with acute coronary artery reocclusion.

C) INCORRECT:

Ventricular free wall rupture typically manifests with acute hemodynamic collapse and cardiac tamponade. This patient is hemodynamically stable with normal vital signs.

D) INCORRECT:

Ventricular septal defect manifests with a holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border and signs of right heart failure. This patient's displaced apical impulse and anterior ST elevations are not consistent with a septal defect.

E) INCORRECT:

Papillary muscle rupture causes acute severe mitral regurgitation with pulmonary edema and respiratory distress. This patient's clinical presentation is primarily neurological, not cardiac.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presents with chest pain and dyspnea 10 days after hospital discharge for MI. Vital signs are BP, 92/58; P, 108. Echocardiogram is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate anticoagulation and arrange cardiology follow-up
Consult cardiothoracic surgery for urgent repair
Perform pericardiocentesis and admit for monitoring
Consult cardiology for left heart catheterization with ventriculography

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharge with delayed surgical referral is inappropriate for pseudoaneurysms because of the high rupture risk. Immediate rather than elective intervention is required.

B) INCORRECT:

Anticoagulation therapy may be considered for left ventricular aneurysms with thrombus formation. However, this patient has a ventricular pseudoaneurysm rather than a ventricular aneurysm, and anticoagulation therapy is not appropriate for pseudoaneurysms.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- The echocardiogram shows a left ventricular pseudoaneurysm, which carries a high risk of rupture and cardiac tamponade. This patient's hemodynamic instability and clinical presentation warrant urgent surgical repair to prevent complete rupture and death.

D) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous drainage is used to treat pericardial effusion, not pseudoaneurysm. Pseudoaneurysms require definitive surgical repair to prevent free rupture and cardiovascular collapse.

E) INCORRECT:

Ventriculography is considered the gold standard for distinguishing between left ventricular aneurysm and pseudoaneurysm, but it is an invasive procedure and echocardiography has already confirmed the diagnosis.
